articles.headline: Russian Artists Face a Choice: Censor Themselves, or Else
articles.snippet: Cultural figures in Russia describe a climate of anxiety as laws banning obscenities have made them compromise their work or face harsh penalties.
articles.abstract: Cultural figures in Russia describe a climate of anxiety as laws banning obscenities have made them compromise their work or face harsh penalties.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — After a law went into effect last summer banning obscenities in public performances, the playwright and director Ivan Vyrypaev excised the curse words from one of his plays, “The Drunks,” for its Russian debut at the prestigious Moscow Art Theater. Some actors played the new version straight, he said, while others winked to make clear what was cut.

articles.headline: Norway Reverts to Cold War Mode as Russian Air Patrols Spike
articles.snippet: The Russian moves have set off debate over military spending and highlighted how quickly President Vladimir V. Putin has shredded the certainties of the post-Cold War era.
articles.abstract: The Russian moves have set off debate over military spending and highlighted how quickly President Vladimir V. Putin has shredded the certainties of the post-Cold War era.
articles.lead_paragraph: BODO, Norway — From his command post burrowed deep into a mountain of quartz and slate north of the Arctic Circle, the 54-year-old commander of the Norwegian military’s operations headquarters watches time flowing backward, pushed into reverse by surging Russian military activity redolent of East-West sparring during the Cold War.

articles.headline: The PayPal Mafia’s Golden Touch
articles.snippet: Alumni from the payments company have established a reputation as the best in Silicon Valley at finding and funding the latest hot product or company.
articles.abstract: Alumni from the payments company have established a reputation as the best in Silicon Valley at finding and funding the latest hot product or company.
articles.lead_paragraph: The ride-hailing app Uber, the apartment rental site Airbnb and other darlings of the next generation of Silicon Valley start-ups are reshaping the way people use the web. They are also changing expectations about just how much money private companies can raise while still staying out of the public markets.

articles.headline: Prosecutors Ease Crackdown on Buyers of China-Bound Luxury Cars
articles.snippet: Federal authorities in South Carolina, Florida, Georgia and Ohio have settled these export disputes by returning all of the seized cars.
articles.abstract: Federal authorities in South Carolina, Florida, Georgia and Ohio have settled these export disputes by returning all of the seized cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: A luxury car exporter’s nearly two-year legal battle to recover a Porsche Cayenne and $120,786 seized by United States authorities has ended with federal prosecutors in South Carolina agreeing to return the property and drop a civil forfeiture lawsuit.

articles.headline: California Imposes First Mandatory Water Restrictions to Deal With Drought
articles.snippet: The move by Gov. Jerry Brown comes as California’s drought has reached near-crisis proportions after a winter that brought record-low snowfalls.
articles.abstract: The move by Gov. Jerry Brown comes as California’s drought has reached near-crisis proportions after a winter that brought record-low snowfalls.
articles.lead_paragraph: PHILLIPS, Calif. — Gov. Jerry Brown on Wednesday ordered mandatory water use reductions for the first time in California’s history, saying the state’s four-year drought had reached near-crisis proportions after a winter of record-low snowfalls.

articles.headline: Oil Glut Is a Boon to Shippers, as Buyers Stock Up at Low Prices
articles.snippet: Although petroleum prices are down worldwide, the business of sending supertankers across the seas has never been brisker — or more global.
articles.abstract: Although petroleum prices are down worldwide, the business of sending supertankers across the seas has never been brisker — or more global.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Jonathan Lee has spent 30 years in the shipping business. But he was as excited as a rookie over the scene on his screen one recent day here at the international nerve center of his oil tanker chartering and dispatching company.

articles.headline: McDonald’s to Raise Pay at Outlets It Operates
articles.snippet: A day after nationwide protests, the company said it was raising wages at least $1 over the local minimum wage at the restaurants it operates. Franchise outlets may feel new pressure.
articles.abstract: A day after nationwide protests, the company said it was raising wages at least $1 over the local minimum wage at the restaurants it operates. Franchise outlets may feel new pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: McDonald’s announced on Wednesday that it would raise wages and offer new benefits to 90,000 employees in the 1,500 outlets in the United States that it owns and operates, responding to competitive pressure from a tighter job market and to labor campaigns drawing public attention to its pay policies.

articles.headline: Walmart Emerges as Unlikely Social Force
articles.snippet: The company posted a statement in its Twitter feed that asked the governor of Arkansas, its home state, to reject legislation that critics say could allow discrimination against lesbians and gay men.
articles.abstract: The company posted a statement in its Twitter feed that asked the governor of Arkansas, its home state, to reject legislation that critics say could allow discrimination against lesbians and gay men.
articles.lead_paragraph: Walmart, which has deployed its financial might to squeeze extra gallons of gas out of its trucks and shave pennies off the price of laundry detergent, did something unexpected this week: It muscled its way into a divisive social debate.
articles.byline: By Hiroko Tabuchi and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Rights Measures Expose Divisions in G.O.P.’s Ranks
articles.snippet: State laws seen as discriminatory against gay couples have laid bare and intensified fissures between social conservatives and the pro-business wing of the party.
articles.abstract: State laws seen as discriminatory against gay couples have laid bare and intensified fissures between social conservatives and the pro-business wing of the party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In Indiana, the Republican mayor of Indianapolis argued against the law the Republican governor had signed. In Ohio, a group called the Young Conservatives for the Freedom to Marry tried to remove antigay language from the party platform. In Arkansas, the Republican governor faced a backlash from business and asked the Republican-led legislature to recall a bill seen as discriminatory to same-sex couples.

articles.headline: Somali Militants Kill 147 at Kenyan University
articles.snippet: Shabab militants claimed responsibility for an attack in which gunmen forced their way into dormitories, leaving 147 people dead.
articles.abstract: Shabab militants claimed responsibility for an attack in which gunmen forced their way into dormitories, leaving 147 people dead.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Somali militants burst into a university in eastern Kenya on Thursday and killed nearly 150 students in the worst terrorist attack since the 1998 bombing of the United States Embassy here, laying bare the nation’s continuing vulnerability after years of battling Islamist extremism.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Isma'il Kushkush and Rukmini Callimachi

articles.headline: Saudi Leaders Have High Hopes for Yemen Airstrikes, but Houthi Attacks Continue
articles.snippet: King Salman of Saudi Arabia bet his prestige as a new leader on rallying his Arab allies for a campaign to save Yemen from an Iranian takeover. The results showed just how large a risk they took.
articles.abstract: King Salman of Saudi Arabia bet his prestige as a new leader on rallying his Arab allies for a campaign to save Yemen from an Iranian takeover. The results showed just how large a risk they took.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Two months after ascending to the throne, King Salman of Saudi Arabia bet his prestige as a new leader on rallying his Arab allies for a military campaign to save Yemen from an Iranian takeover — all under the direction of his son, the new defense minister and chief of the royal court.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kareem Fahim

articles.headline: The Chinese Billionaire Zhang Lei Spins Research Into Investment Gold
articles.snippet: Zhang Lei got his break as an intern for Yale’s endowment, which he impressed so much with his detailed reports that it gave him $20 million to invest.
articles.abstract: Zhang Lei got his break as an intern for Yale’s endowment, which he impressed so much with his detailed reports that it gave him $20 million to invest.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — With an $18 billion war chest, he is one of China’s richest investors. Yet on a recent trip to San Francisco, Zhang Lei and his entourage crammed into a three-bedroom house in the Mission District, rented through Airbnb.

articles.headline: Iran Agrees to Detailed Nuclear Outline, First Step Toward a Wider Deal
articles.snippet: An understanding was reached about limiting Iran’s nuclear program, but key issues remain before a final agreement in June.
articles.abstract: An understanding was reached about limiting Iran’s nuclear program, but key issues remain before a final agreement in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAUSANNE, Switzerland — Iran and the United States, along with five other world powers, announced on Thursday a surprisingly specific and comprehensive understanding on limiting Tehran’s nuclear program for the next 15 years, though they left several specific issues to a final agreement in June.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: G.M. Bets Big on a Resurgent Cadillac
articles.snippet: Cadillac used to be synonymous with American style, quality and prestige. Now, with a new model and a move, General Motors is trying to recapture the swagger.
articles.abstract: Cadillac used to be synonymous with American style, quality and prestige. Now, with a new model and a move, General Motors is trying to recapture the swagger.
articles.lead_paragraph: I learned to drive in my father’s black 1967 Cadillac, which my friends and I called the “Batmobile.” With its fins, 130-inch wheelbase and 4,675 pounds, there was no mistaking it for a Mercedes, not that any of us back then had ever seen one.
